Speaking at the annual Commemoration Day banquet of the Hopkins
Alumni Association at the Hotel Belvedere on Monday evening, President
Bowman held'out the probability that
enrollment at the Hopkins will drop
__thirty, or even fifty, per cent if the
war lasts for two more years. Of
cutting down on "non-essentials," he
asked, "Who except a Solomon can
determine what they are? We could
cut faculty salaries, but we don't want
to do that in the face of rising prices."
Dr Bowman was addressing nearly
200 alumni on The University in Wartime. He said that the most spectacular contributions of the University
to the war effort have been in the
fields of medicine and engineering.
He cited the creation under Dr
Lewis Hill Weed, director of the
medical school, of thirty committees
to engage in research on specific medical problems related to the war. In
addition to expanding its research
activities, the medical school is faced,
Dr Bowman said, by the necessity
of turning out the greatly increased
numbers of doctors required by the
armed forces. "When we realize that
six times as many physicians and surgeons are required for an army in the
field as for a normal civilian population, we still have quite a problem,"
the president warned.
Among wartime activities of the
engineering school, he mentioned -the
offering of short six- to ,ten-week
courses in specific industrial skills.
He also called attention to intensive
language courses in modern Greek,
Arabic, and Icelandic.
Dr Harvey B Stone, president of the
alumni assiciation acted as toastmaster for the banquet.,Repots werL
made by Roszel C Thomsen, vice pre
ident, and Horace E Flack, treasurer.

To write about the work of a poet is to pick him up by the tie, hang
him on a rack, label him Warner Brothers' or Al Stein's, pin on a price
tag, and offer him for sale to the reader. In other words, a reviewer, whether,
he is a professional or amateur, is no more than a retail merchant. No matter
who the merchant and no matter what his price, the final say, of course, lies
with the reader. This amounts to a personal apology to Karl Shapiro for
reviewing his poems; for he maintains to his poetry falls "the task of
destroying the government of critics and of making a wholesale return to
the anarchy of experience."
